articles.title: Article 1
paragraphs: India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States. It highlights the official name of the country and its nature as a union of states.
The territory of India shall comprise the territories of the States, Union territories, and any acquired territories.
The states and the union territories of India form an integral part of the country, and no state has the right to secede.

articles.title: Article 2
paragraphs: Empowers Parliament to admit new states into the Union of India and establish new states.
Parliament may by law admit new states into the Union or establish new states on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.
This power gives flexibility for future expansion of Indiaâ€™s territory, whether by peaceful means or otherwise.

articles.title: Article 3
paragraphs: Provides the procedure for the formation of new states and alteration of areas, boundaries, or names of existing states.
Parliament may by law form a new state, increase the area of any state, or alter the boundaries or names of any existing state.
A bill for this purpose can only be introduced with the recommendation of the President after consulting the concerned state legislature.

articles.title: Article 4
paragraphs: Lays down that laws made for admission or establishment of new states, or altering the boundaries or names of existing states, are not considered amendments under Article 368.
Such laws require only a simple majority in Parliament, not a constitutional amendment.
This Article ensures that the reorganization of states can be done more easily, without requiring the complex procedure of a constitutional amendment.

articles.title: Article 5
paragraphs: Deals with citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution.
It grants citizenship to people domiciled in India at the time of the commencement of the Constitution.
The provision includes people born in India, people residing in India for at least five years, and people of Indian origin.
